questions.promptMd: Which apology pattern MOST supports trust repair?

answers.contentMd: Acknowledge impact → specific apology → remedy plan with dates → verification
answers.feedbackMd: Complete sequence shows ownership and competence.

answers.contentMd: "We’re sorry if you felt…" + no specifics
Blame third parties + promise to "do better"
Silence until fixed to avoid attention

questions.promptMd: True or False: Offering make‑good options without acknowledging impact is sufficient in most cases.

answers.feedbackMd: Acknowledge impact explicitly; repair is both emotional and practical.
Correct. Recognition of harm is foundational to repair.

questions.promptMd: Which follow‑up MOST credibly closes the loop after an incident?

answers.contentMd: Post‑mortem with root causes, fixes, owners, and dates; share verification results
A vague email stating "we improved things"
A marketing blog about future vision

questions.promptMd: True or False: Trust often rebounds higher than baseline after a well‑handled failure.

answers.feedbackMd: Correct. Competent recovery can strengthen relationships.
Handled well, failures can build trust.
